Idiom (Gilbertese): E aki manga kan te kaina te kai ni manga
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Negative clause with habitual verb phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Describes a lazy or unproductive person who avoids effort or responsibility.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A person who does not like to work.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in South Tarawa; derived from the image of someone refusing to chew hard food—symbol of laziness.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): e ˈaki ˈmaŋa kan te ˈkai̯na te ˈkai ni ˈmaŋa
First Example Sentence: E aki manga kan te kaina te kai ni manga, e aki riki bwa e kona ni karaoa bwaai.
Second Example Sentence: Ao n te maneaba, e taetae naba bwa ‘e aki manga kan te kaina te kai ni manga’ bwa e mwaiti ni kakabwai.
Third Example Sentence: Te mwaane aio e bon taetae bwa e aki manga kan te kaina te kai ni manga.

Idiom (Gilbertese): Te nakoan te reirei e aki manga oti
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed nominal clause with negative completion aspect
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means that learning or wisdom never ends.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional saying used by elders to encourage lifelong learning.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): te naˈkoan te ˈɾei̯ɾei e ˈaki ˈmaŋa ˈoti
First Example Sentence: E taetae bwa te nakoan te reirei e aki manga oti n te reirei maneaba.
Second Example Sentence: Te tiaon te mwane e taetae bwa te nakoan te reirei e aki manga oti, e kona ni kairake.
Third Example Sentence: E mwaiti bwa te nakoan te reirei e aki manga oti naba i nanon te aba.

Idiom (Gilbertese): Te riki ni ataei e bon aki riki n te kaba
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means that skill is not inherited but learned through practice.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: One must practice to gain skill.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Old proverb from Abemama atoll emphasizing diligence in craft learning.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): te ˈɾiki ni aˈtaei̯ e ˈbɔn ˈaki ˈɾiki n te ˈkapa
First Example Sentence: E taetae bwa te riki ni ataei e bon aki riki n te kaba.
Second Example Sentence: Ko manga reirei bwa te riki ni ataei e bon aki riki n te kaba.
Third Example Sentence: Te mwaane aio e taetae bwa te riki ni ataei e bon aki riki n te kaba.

Idiom (Gilbertese): Te koro n taeka e aki manga boki
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Nominal clause with negative verb phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Refers to someone who speaks but does not act; a hypocrite or talker.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Someone who talks but does not do anything.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from communal observations during village debates at the maneaba.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): te ˈkɔɾo n taˈeka e ˈaki ˈmaŋa ˈboki
First Example Sentence: Te mwaane aio e bon te koro n taeka e aki manga boki.
Second Example Sentence: Ao e taetae naba bwa e aki mwaane, te koro n taeka e aki manga boki.
Third Example Sentence: E aki manga mwaiti bwa e kona naba bwa te koro n taeka e aki manga boki.

Idiom (Gilbertese): Te kaoti n te mwaane e na manga kabane
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Noun phrase with future auxiliary construction
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means that hard work leads to success or reward.
Usage Contexts: Motivational speech, family life, work, education
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional moral idiom tied to fishing and daily work routines.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): te kaˈoti n te ˈmwaane e na ˈmaŋa kaˈbane
First Example Sentence: E taetae bwa te kaoti n te mwaane e na manga kabane.
Second Example Sentence: E bon mwaiti bwa te kaoti n te mwaane e na manga kabane i nanon te kaawa.
Third Example Sentence: Ko manga taetae bwa te kaoti n te mwaane e na manga kabane.

Idiom (Gilbertese): Te nakoan te bwain te moan e bon aoraki te botanaomata
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means that appearance can deceive; not all that glitters is gold.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Do not judge people by appearance.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Ancestral wisdom comparing deceitful people to the ocean’s deceptive calm.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): te naˈkoan te ˈbwai̯n te ˈmoan e ˈbɔn aɔˈɾaki te botaˈnaɔmata
First Example Sentence: E bon mwaiti bwa te nakoan te bwain te moan e bon aoraki te botanaomata.
Second Example Sentence: E taetae bwa e kona bwa te nakoan te bwain te moan e bon aoraki te botanaomata.
Third Example Sentence: Ko manga reirei bwa te nakoan te bwain te moan e bon aoraki te botanaomata.

Idiom (Gilbertese): Te kateintain ae e aki manga kanganga
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means that a person who never listens to advice causes their own downfall.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional lesson about humility and listening to elders’ wisdom.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): te kateinˈtain ae e ˈaki ˈmaŋa kaŋaŋa
First Example Sentence: E mwaiti bwa te kateintain ae e aki manga kanganga.
Second Example Sentence: E taetae bwa e aki kona ni kanganga bwa te kateintain ae e aki manga kanganga.
Third Example Sentence: Te mwane aio e aki mwaane bwa te kateintain ae e aki manga kanganga.

Idiom (Gilbertese): Te koro ni mwenga e aki manga karekea bwa te koro
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means that a secret or lie will eventually be revealed.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: The truth will always come out.
Usage Contexts: Family, community life, gossip, moral sayings
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from community conflict resolution practices in maneaba discussions.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): te ˈkɔɾo ni ˈmwɛŋa e ˈaki ˈmaŋa kaɾeˈkea bwa te ˈkɔɾo
First Example Sentence: E mwaiti bwa te koro ni mwenga e aki manga karekea bwa te koro.
Second Example Sentence: Ko taetae bwa te koro ni mwenga e aki manga karekea bwa te koro.
Third Example Sentence: Te mwaane aio e bon mwaiti bwa te koro ni mwenga e aki manga karekea bwa te koro.

Idiom (Gilbertese): Te nakoan te ririki e aki manga oti
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means that the path of struggle never truly ends; perseverance is lifelong.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common poetic metaphor in traditional chants and elder advice.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): te naˈkoan te ɾiɾiˈki e ˈaki ˈmaŋa ˈoti
First Example Sentence: E taetae bwa te nakoan te ririki e aki manga oti i nanon te aba.
Second Example Sentence: E mwaiti bwa te nakoan te ririki e aki manga oti i nanon te kabane.
Third Example Sentence: Ko mwaiti bwa te nakoan te ririki e aki manga oti naba.

Idiom (Gilbertese): Te nakoan te kaawa e aki manga tia
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Negative nominal clause with habitual action
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means that one cannot escape the consequences of their actions.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in Kiribati’s communal value of accountability and justice.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Gilbertese): te naˈkoan te kaˈawa e ˈaki ˈmaŋa ˈtia
First Example Sentence: E mwaiti bwa te nakoan te kaawa e aki manga tia.
Second Example Sentence: E taetae bwa te nakoan te kaawa e aki manga tia n te maneaba.
Third Example Sentence: Ko taetae bwa te nakoan te kaawa e aki manga tia naba.
